value: <l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">26</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#psn-espe" key="Spenser, Edmund">Spenser</rs> with his eye upon the reader in the great room.</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">Yet the audience for all its size and compulsion is silent.</l>

<add xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" place="margin">
            <l>If we</l>
            <l><choice>
              <sic>cd.</sic>
              <corr>could</corr>
            </choice> measure</l>
            <l>the effect</l>
            <l>of the audience</l>
            <l>we <choice>
              <sic>shd.</sic>
              <corr>should</corr>
            </choice></l>
            <l>have a hold</l>
            <l>upon the</l>
            <l>play.</l>
          </add>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">That is one of the deep gulfs that lies between us</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">and the play. They crowd there; daily; but they neither</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">
            <choice>
              <sic>priase</sic>
              <corr>praise</corr>
            </choice> nor blame. We must compare it with our 
            <choice>
              <sic>won</sic>
              <corr>own</corr>
            </choice> 
            <choice>
              <sic>sielnce</sic>
              <corr>silence</corr>
            </choice></l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">at the <rs type="literary-work" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#lit-balle" key="Ballet Russes">Russian ballet</rs> or the <rs type="literary-work" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#lit-cine" key="Cinema">
            <choice>
              <sic>cima</sic>
              <corr>cinema</corr>
            </choice>, in their early days.</rs></l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">A new art comes upon us so 
            <choice>
              <sic>surpinsgly</sic>
              <corr>surprisingly</corr>
            </choice> that we sit</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">silent, recognising what we cannot measure.</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">To the Elizabethans the expressive power of words</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">after their long inadequacy 
            <choice>
              <sic>ust</sic>
              <corr>must</corr>
            </choice> have been overwhelming.</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">There at the <rs type="place" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#pla-glob" key="Globe, The">
            <choice>
              <sic>Glove</sic>
              <corr>Globe</corr>
            </choice></rs> or at the <rs type="place" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#pla-rose" key="Rose, The">Rose</rs> men and women whose only</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">reading had been the Bible or some old 
            <choice>
              <sic>chonicle</sic>
              <corr>chronicle</corr>
            </choice> came out</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">into the light of the present moment. They saw themselves</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">splendidly dressed. They heard 
            <choice>
              <sic>themslves</sic>
              <corr>themselves</corr>
            </choice> saying out loud</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">what they had never said yet. They heard their aspirations,</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">their profanities, their 
            <choice>
              <sic>ribaldires</sic>
              <corr>ribaldries</corr>
            </choice> spoken out loud by human</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">voices in poetry.</l>
<add xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" place="margin"><!-- come back to this on the big screen --></add>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">The play then owes its hyperbole to the audience in the</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">penny seats. At their command it is 
            <choice>
              <sic>vio;ent</sic>
              <corr>violent</corr>
            </choice>; it xmxmxmmxmx</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">it is coarse; it is poexxx xmxmxmxm a parody, of actual</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">facts. like our own detective stories and best sellers</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">a 
            <choice>
              <sic>paody</sic>
              <corr>parody</corr>
            </choice> a 
            <choice>
              <sic>trasnformation</sic>
              <corr>transformation</corr>
            </choice> of actual fact. But in the seats</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">in the covered part of the house, there were nobles, rulers,</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">scholars. Their 
            <choice>
              <sic>silenc</sic>
              <corr>silence</corr>
            </choice> is harder to explain. For they were</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">
            <choice>
              <sic>redares</sic>
              <corr>readers</corr>
            </choice>; they had the Latins and the Greeks at the back</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">of their minds. How could it have been that the trained</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">taste of such 
            <choice>
              <sic>speactoars</sic>
              <corr>spectators</corr>
            </choice> received the extraordinary</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">illumination of these English plays with no more comment</l>

<add xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" place="margin">
            <l>said nothing</l>
            <l>about the</l>
            <l>[revelation?],</l>
            <l>was not</l>
            <l>outraged, by</l>
            <l>an excited</l>
            <l>- as seems to be the <del hand="ms">common</del> reader to a [illeg.] </l>
          </add>
